I'm not sure how much this has been discussed but I'd like to think I keep pretty up to date on all things SpaceX (Thanks to you, a few other great YouTubers and a bit of my own digging). I have yet to see any information regarding the role NASA @JimBridenstine or any other government agencies (FAA) roles would be in regards to the regulation of SpaceX point to point transport. I'd love to see some information regarding a plan for this and the steps the Government would want to see SpaceX take to make this a reality. This would be a great subject for me if you get another chance to talk with Jim Bridenstine. I'm not sure how much would fall under the FAA and how much would fall under NASA but I'm guessing a large portion of both agencies. I'm guessing they would need a much more rigorous standard than just the standard Human-rating certification that are given out considering the large amount of civilians that would be traveling at any giving time. I'm so excited for this opportunity in the future but at the same time I worry about it significantly. A single RUD could cripple SpaceX plans to reach Mars and further. With Elons goal in mind I feel like this direction while it does increase profits might be more risk than it is worth. I believe that it may be best to just focus on Starlink to mitigate risks and in turn Elon has a much higher chance of success in his ultimate unwavering goal to make humans a multi-planetary species. I'd love to hear other people thoughts on this matter.

He should be pressed, publicly, hard and repeatedly on Orion/SLS. They are direct linear descendants of Apollo/Saturn V, with no substantially new or different technology of any significant nature. SLS first stage is a rework of the STS External Tank & SDCV, which was a rework of Saturn V. Merely expanding the diameter to accommodate a couple more passengers and stay aloft a few days longer, is not some radical advance from Apollo. So, Apollo/Saturn V went from final concept to launch in five years; Orion/SLS has been in the works for more than 20 years (previously named Ares V) thus far without result, and nobody is asking, answering or being held to account for this Highway Robbery of the Taxpayer. Bridenstein is especially vulnerable to this question as a former Deficit Hawk in Congress. No one says the American telescope James Webb, or the American probe Juno. Science has no borders, and the nation of the telescope is not really relevant. But when it comes to boldly going where no one has gone before, these spiritual factors become relevant. The James Webb telescope will be launched by a European rocket, probably in French Guiana soil, and that's not a problem at all. What is really important is that it will look at the beginning of time, and humanity as a whole will benefit from that.

Ask NASA what the average timespan has been for their unmanned programs in the "development" phase; then, ask NASA what the average timespan has been for their manned programs in the "development" phase. Sorry. The word "lame" comes to mind when explaining why merely sending a capsule to the space station takes so long. It was 98 months from Kennedy's "landing a man on the moon" speech to actually LANDING a man on the moon and bringing him safely home to Earth. Now, it's also been 98 months (and counting) since retiring the Shuttle program--the most complex spacecraft ever designed and produced--to landing a man on the space station with a simple capsule. "Testing. Data. Temperature. Pressure. Development. Blah blah blah." Please don't tell me that you think the Russian's have done anywhere's NEAR the testing, data collection, temperature and pressure analyses and CAD development with Soyuz, but you're more than willing to send Americans up and down in their funky cans. You really think their ancient, $70MM/seat Soyuz capsule is SAFER than what Spacex has developed? Really? Because if you say, "Well, they've had so many successful missions with it, though," doesn't that negate the 'we-don't-know-what-we-don't-know-so-we-need-to-test-the-stew-out-of-it-instead-of-fly-it' argument?


I was very critical of the slipshod safety record of the Space Shuttles and NASA's willingness to risk human life in favor of keeping an aggressive flight schedule. But, it really seems that the pendulum has swung just as far the other way. Unlike any other vessels, Crew Dragon has a dual landing system. (I really doubt that the SuperDraco engines are going to be ignored as a backup emergency landing system. Nothing wrong with it, but validating a powered landing system as primary is going to take into the next century.) Aside from one instance of deliberately making a chute fail (probably causing the other chutes to malfunction), all other "parachute-out" tests have been solid. And, none of the returning supply Dragon capsule parachutes have ever failed as far as I remember. Let's go, NASA. The universe is getting old.

Tim, congratulations on snagging this interview with the NASA Administrator! I love your enthusiasm for space and all that’s entailed in getting there. I’m also happy that I had the opportunity to meet you at the Live podcast event in Vista!

Jim was excellent in putting forth the NASA talking points during your session, most of which he spoke during the session with Elon. And that’s fine, I wouldn’t expect much different.

However, as you get more and more access to Elon, Jim and others, there is a fine line between being an enthusiast and a reporter, and that is (when appropriate) pushing back about what is being said by the interviewee. Jim basically said that the Gateway was the only way, spoke about SLS as if it was a great on-schedule, on-budget program, and wove a story that in effect said that everything NASA is doing is right.

Your comment on budget and schedule at the outset of the interview provided an opportunity to find out more about where we stand to actually achieving a return to the Lunar Surface by 26 March 2024 (exactly five years since announcement of the goal). People have said, that NASA is underfunded to achieve that goal—does Jim agree? If so, then schedule will slip, unless there are risk mitigation efforts.

So keep up the good work, but try to question more of the things that are said, especially when you hear “talking points” being robotically voiced.

Thanks again for all that you do for space enthusiasts! —G
